article_title: Cheese has 'morphine-like' qualities, can be addictive
article_text:
That's the conclusion of a doctor and author who says that cheese has "morphine-like compounds" called casomorphins that attach to the brain's opiate receptors, making the food even harder to resist than its high levels of fat and salt already do on their own, according to a report in Thrillist, a website on food, drink and travel.

"In cheese, we get massive concentrations of fat and salt, which our highly evolved brains continue to love. Combine this with the opioid-like casomorphins, and cheese suddenly goes from 'very delicious' to 'obscenely tempting,'" the report said.

article_metadata.description: If you're the type of person who can't stop eating cheese once you start, it may not be your fault. You may be addicted.
article_metadata.author: Ted Kemp

og.description: If you're the type of person who can't stop eating cheese once you start, it may not be your fault. You may be addicted.
og.title: 'Morphine-like' cheese can be physically addictive

article_summary:
Combine this with the opioid-like casomorphins, and cheese suddenly goes from 'very delicious' to 'obscenely tempting,'" the report said.
"In cheese, we get massive concentrations of fat and salt, which our highly evolved brains continue to love.
That's the conclusion of a doctor and author who says that cheese has "morphine-like compounds" called casomorphins that attach to the brain's opiate receptors, making the food even harder to resist than its high levels of fat and salt already do on their own, according to a report in Thrillist, a website on food, drink and travel.
